posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14529672

One main part of the first book is combining psychoanalysis and historical materialism. IE, desire and libidinal desire isn't just a superstructural element of society but actually part of the material, economic, infrastructural "base" of society, and every unconscious libidinal investment is social and bears upon a socio-historical field.

>The truth is sexuality is everywhere: the way a bureaucrat fondles his records, a judge administers justice, a businessman causes money to circulate; the way the bourgeoisie fucks the proletariat; and so on. [...] Flags, nations, armies, banks get a lot of people aroused.

As an outgrowth of this, the next argument is that 'desire' as discussed historically is not merely an abstract impulse that emerges in the theatre of the unconscious (as Freud would see it), and it is not just concerned with acquisition, ie the desire to acquire things (as Plato would see it). Instead, desire is a positive process of production that produces reality, a machine that engineers and manufactures its own objects, its own self-replication, and its own autopoiesis. This was influenced by Nietzsche's will to power and Spinoza's conatus.
This is then applied to the concept of social reproduction, as in the reproduction and repetition of certain social modes in a given society. Since desire produces reality, social production, with its forces and relations, is purely and simply desiring-production itself under determinate conditions. They argue, thus, that the social universe is composed of 'desiring-machines', all connected to one another and involved in the production and reproduction of desires, which form the individual pieces of much of social reality, like the cells of a body.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14529672
>>14535467

This concept is fundamental to the book, and from it the notion of the Anti-Oedipus. Freud argues that the Oedipus complex represents an area in which the unconscious and desire is central to the social world - in the tripartite structure of the family (mother, father, offspring). However, the Anti-Oedipus shows that it's foolish to argue that the social world is solely made up of tripartite families, and instead it is an interconnected flow of different desires and the production of said desires by the desiring machines (ie humans).

From that standpoint, the concept of the desiring machine, they begin to interrogate how capitalism relates to this production of desire, and how it predicates itself upon the repression of some desiring machines, which leads to neurosis. The argument, then, is that schizophrenia is an extreme mental state co-existent with the capitalist system itself.

'Desire' here is obviously a broad term, but they were influenced by the discoveries of geneticists and the self-replication of genes - the 'desire' for self-replication, survival, procreation showing that desire was not merely an aberrant impulse to acquire, but rather a fundamental productive force. From there, they develop the concept of a 'body without organs' - ie the unregulated potential of a body without organisational structures imposed on its constituent parts by the necessities of biological homeostasis, the need to eat, sleep, breath, and instead one that is formed of combinations of desiring machines. This is when desire moves from the base to the superstructure, and can enter the world of more abstract concepts - no longer the desire of an individual, but the desire of a company, of a class, of a nation, of a civilisation. Desire is not limited to the affections of a subject, nor the material state of the subject.

From there, they move on to discuss territorialization, deterritorialization and reterritorialization, which intentionally vary in definition throughout their work, but initially means the movement of an assemblage (the heterogeneous composition of any complex system, including an individual system, social system, an economic system) from one state to another, via a middle ground of deterritorialization. Territorialization is maintenance, deterritorialization is dissipation, and reterritorialization is re-maintenance.
So, if a social system or system of relations could be argued to be made up of desiring machines, producing and interacting in a constant flow, then gradually they will acclimate and balance into some form of structure (territory). Then, when there is a foundational shift, that current organization and context will be altered, mutated or destroyed, and the components will then constitute a new territory, which is the process of reterritorialization. This process is explored in greater depth in A Thousand Plateaus, which explains how it can all be placed within the rhizomatic world.

>>14532551

This is partially true within the concept of 'schizoanalysis' that they use to counter what they describe as the 'reactionary' aspects of Freudian and Jungian psychoanalysis. They were also influenced by anti-psychiatrists like RD Laing although they weren't anti-psychiatrists.
The relationship between schizophrenia (in a non-clinical, purely social sense) and capitalism is posited thus: capitalism requires the repression of some behaviours and desires, and the promotions of others. Thus, it involves the hegemony of some desiring machines within the system of social relations, and these can be described as hegemonic complexes of desire - the desire for military growth, for economic prosperity, or the desire for a civil society, or the desire for medical governance, etc etc. These hegemonic complexes were often associated, by Deleuze and Guattari, with the sort of hegemonic forces left wingers or Marxists might complain about, but the actual point of schizoanalysis means that it isn't a critique of left or right wing - since desiring machines exist in both sides. As much as a military desire complex may suppress pacifist desires, a civil, egalitarian desire complex may suppress the will to dominance and power.
Essentially, to function, hegemonic capitalism must repress and quash these nonconforming desiring machines, to preserve 'normality'.

It's not an evidence-based approach, no, because they're not seeking to create a uniform practice about social reality. Also, they're not scientists. It's limited heavily by the fact it is continental philosophy, so there's always a lot of guff, but the argument from lay critics is often that it doesn't make internal sense or is just a load of rambling nonsense which, at least for the first book, is unfair. It does follow a rationale and continues on from generations of philosophical thought, taking from Spinoza, Kant, Hegel, Marx, Freud, etc., and the concept of the desiring machine and desiring-production is well-fleshed out and explored in depth. I think it fails to land with Anglo audiences because the English translations always do sounds pretty schizoid and wishy-washy.

>desires producing reality

This is not the argument. The argument is that desire is a socially productive force, in that it dominates and directs social relations rather than just sublimating into perversity (as Freud argued), and thus forms a fundamental substrate to the workings of society, so, social reality, not noumenal reality itself (that's explored in the plane of immanence). This might seem like a pretty blatant observation, and it is the same sort of concept that is now more orthodox in modern social sciences. It's been argued that the game theory of Von Neumann and Nash is part of the mathematics of desire-production and flows (ie mapping strategic interactions amongst rational agents). If it seems like a complicated way to say something fairly obvious, well, welcome to philosophy.

>>14535678

There are two intended meanings:

1) The simple and literal meaning is that, yes, desire engineers the reality around it in the service of the autopoiesis (self-replication) of the unconscious. This is modelled on Kant and his transcendental apperception, which isn't about reality as the Ding an sich (thing-in-itself), ie objective reality independent of representation and observation, but rather reality as it is experienced. Kant argued that much of our experience of what we imagine to be objective reality, i.e. the space and time around us, are actually the forms of intuition via which we structure our experience. Your perception of light isn't the objective nature of light as a thing-in-itself, but rather light as it is observed by the self. Your perception of time isn't the objective nature of time as a thing-in-itself, but rather time as it is observed by the self. While the things-in-themselves do exist, they are distinct from our experience of them. From this it follows that the objects of our experience are mere 'appearances' and that the nature of things as they are in themselves is unknowable to us. You can compare this to the allegory of the cave, or even to the observer effect in quantum mechanics (which relies on advanced forms of mechanical intuition). This is the basic argument behind Kant's epistemological programme, which he called transcendental idealism. It has been an epistemological argument that philosophers have grappled with since the 18th century. Russell and the analytics opposed it with naïve realism, which argues that no, we can trust our perception, the world is knowable as it really is, without any consideration of the knower's manner of knowing. This has always struck me as putting your fingers in your ears and going 'La La La'. Applied metaphysical realism to me is like the healthy vegetable of philosophy - it has done us a lot of good so far, it keeps our bowels in check, but it is far from the whole story.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14535678
>>14535762

Attached is a map of Kant's model of coherent consciousness (an issue which is still challenging us today under the new guise of the 'consciousness and binding problem'). Deleuze and Guattari basically repurpose this and apply it specifically to desire, desire as an investment or cathexis, meaning a concept or object that is allocated mental, emotional or even physical energy. If desire is allocated less energy, it becomes a libidinal investment rather than a direct investment. If your desire is to drink water, and you then immediately follow every course of action to drink water, then that's a direct investment. If your desire is to drink water, but your job, your family, or other social relations require you to de-prioritise that desire and follow other, unrelated courses of desire, then your desire to drink water becomes libidinal - at least until you have the opportunity to drink water.

This leads us to

2) The meaning that is more important to Deleuze and Guattari is that desire is thus, then, a socially productive and reproductive force. The thing driving the development of a social sector, or a social world, or an entire society, economy, civilisation, whatever, is not just the material conditions, but also the ecosystem and flow of desires between the occupants. There is a complex, mutable web of trillions and trillions of desires being produced by desiring machines, and much of this then governs not just the overall shape of social development, but also the junction at which the self and the world come together (as in Kant).

>>14535684

Science did not exist in Plato's time. The difference between science and philosophy wasn't present. The only distinction modern science has is the scientific method and scientific realism, which recommends belief in both observable and unobservable aspects of the world as described by empirical a posteriori practice based on observation, evidence, testing and proof. However, no amount of that can truly contend with the armour piercing question: What proof is there that you are observing and testing the universe as it objectively exists, and not instead simply observing and testing your own objects of experience? How do you know you're measuring the universe to gain and objective piece of information - a fact - instead of gaining an objective piece of information about your experience alone? How do you know you're not just measuring the shadows on the cave wall? It's a really annoying, pointless question, but it can't really be satisfactorily answered. The metaphysical realists have created a million rebuttals (see: post-Hume analytic philosophy), but still cannot escape the shadow of this postulate. In fact, the last 100 years of development in quantum mechanics and other areas of theoretical physics shows us our ideal of a purely mechanical universe in which we are impartial, empirical observers rather than interacting subjects pushes things even further into realms of uncertainty.
This is why science needs philosophy (of course philosophy also needs science, otherwise it wouldn't have anything to ask questions about).

>but beyond scifi books I don't think there are any serious reasons to in a sense 'reject modernity'.

The function of this philosophy then, isn't to serve some societal purpose, but instead to simply interrogate and explore purely for the function of understanding and knowledge. Aristotle referred to θαῦμα (thaûma) in his phenomenology - the notion that conscious experience is a sublime, exhilarating, terrifying experience, yet also somehow quotidian. That, purely by being, every day we run the fearful gauntlet of being in the world, and facing the reality of experience - an almost supernatural event in the eyes of the Greeks. 'Wonder is the only beginning of philosophy', Plato has Socrates say at 155d of the Theaetetus. And at 982b of the Metaphysics Aristotle says, 'it is owing to their wonder that men both now begin and at first began to philosophise'. So this is the fundamental aspect of phenomenology - understanding experience and consciousness, exploring the shape of the inside of our own existence, understanding what it is to experience phenomena and the mental objects, what Husserl calls noemata.
In order to organise your experience of these phenomena, you need to develop an epistemology, or rather an epistemological process, a theory of knowledge. How do I quantify my perceptions of phenomena? How is knowledge formed? How do I justify my theory of knowledge? Is knowledge formed via rationalisation and a priori logic and thought (rationalism)? Or purely by a posteriori experience and investigation (empiricism and positivism)? Or somewhere in between (Kant)? What is the nature of knowledge and the conditions required for a belief to constitute knowledge? How do I define truth? How can I catalogue the nature of the universe as I experience it? Am I cataloguing reality itself or simply my experience of it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14536628
>>14537294


The next step from there is metaphysics, which is, after you've gotten to grips with being in the world, and you've tried to figure out how you know anything about it, you start asking - what is it that exists, and what it is like? You use your epistemological process to organise and study the phenomena you experience and attempt to discover more about the fundamental nature of reality, and see if you can develop some first principles of being, identity and change, space and time, cause and effect, necessity and possibility. This part of metaphysics is called ontology, the study of being and the organisation of being into categories. Much of science comes into this bracket of philosophy - substances, properties, relations, states of affairs and events. Prior to the modern history of science, scientific questions were addressed as a part of natural philosophy. Then, over the Enlightenment, post-Hume, the scientific method came along and transformed natural philosophy into an empirical activity deriving from experiment, unlike the rest of philosophy - driven by empiricism.

The 19th century built on this with positivism (Comte, Darwin, Marx, Durkheim), and then that was brought back down to a much less positivist approach in the 20th century, whether that's more conservative critical rationalism or some of the more radical approaches or what have you (Popper, Kuhn, Feyeraband). However, since the split in the 18th century, metaphysics has denoted philosophical enquiry of a non-empirical character into the nature of existence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14537300
>>14536628

However, where science stops asking "why," metaphysics continues the question. Any theory of basic physics, for instance, is predicated on a set of axioms that may presuppose the existence of things like atoms, particles, forces, charges, mass, or fields. A science theory is said to have reached its "end" when such postulates are made. Metaphysics takes these postulates and examines what they mean in terms of human concepts. Do all theories of physics, for instance, require the presence of space, time, things, and properties? Can they also be expressed solely in terms of objects or properties? Do the objects have to stay the same over time or are they allowed to change? And on and on, ad nauseam.

From there, metaphysics starts getting into THE big question, referred to by philosophers as the "Why is there something rather than nothing?" question. Russell took a 'brute fact' position when he said, "I should say that the universe is just there, and that's all", which is what I call the 'La La La' approach. It if fundamentally incurious and stagnant thinking, and one thing I really don't like about him. The funniest one line response was Morgenbesser:

>If there were nothing you'd still be complaining!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14537310
>>14536628

Leibniz thought that existence could be justified by mathematical necessity - 'Why is there something rather than nothing? The sufficient reason [...] is found in a substance which [...] is a necessary being bearing the reason for its existence within itself.' This is also his mathematical argument for God (cosmological argument). There is something rather than nothing, because the existence of something requires there to be something, rather than nothing. Aristotle's unmoved mover and all that.

Still, this is an issue that metaphysics still contends with and hasn't solved. No matter how much Russell says 'That's all', we're still led into this realm. The scientific method still struggles here, and the more it discovers (quantum mechanics??) the more questions it raises.

It was very important for British philosophers at the start of the 20th century, descended from Hume (a skeptic of rationalism), to distinguish themselves from the Kantian and Hegelian world, German idealism and all of its mess. So Russell and Whitehead were really intent on drawing a clear line between analytical philosophy (good, logic-driven, based on piecemeal induction, relatively empirical, agnostic about metaphysics, ethically naturalist), and continental philosophy (rationalism, idealism, deductive reasoning, bad, bad, not good). The distinction is not as simply as British vs continental, Frege, Carnap and Wittgenstein were very important for analytical philosophy. And these philosophers were tightly intertwined with philosophers of the 'continental' canon, like Husserl and Bergson (Bergson is universally appreciated). The biggest aspect seemed to be about distancing themselves from Kant, Marx, Nietzsche, Heidegger, etc. I would argue that quite a lot of this distinction is pretty broad and political, and in many ways kind of bullshit. I don't think Frege or Husserl (who were corresponders) thought of it in that way.

All we can achieve is an generalised approximation of truth that we can all kind of agree on as a consensus, which obviously serves us in many applications, but still doesn't give us access to the noumenon. We can probably figure out, with enough testing, that we are all touching an elephant, but we still are not directly seeing the elephant outside of subjective phenomena, and we're simply piecemealing our inductive knowledge together to form a 'reality by consensus'. Wittgenstein, messiah of the analytics, faced this in the semiotics of his language-games.

>How does the wave function collapsing in any way imply subjectivity?

While the 'observer' in the observer effect is, yes, simply a physical process as a part of the wider quantum phenomenon and, as Heisenberg says, should not mean that the subjective mind is itself determining reality, the point is that the discovery that measurement itself was a physical process that existed in interplay and interaction with the measured, brings us back to the metaphysical question of what it is we are measuring - the objective reality, or the experience of it? A wave-function may collapse due to observation, which does not mean there isn't an objective reality, but instead that our attempts to measure an objective reality will always be limited by the fact that we, ourselves, are forced to occupy and participate in that objective reality. At the turn of the 20th century, Planck was making discoveries in the study of black-body radiation (On Irreversible Radiation Processes and On the Law of the Energy Distribution in the Normal Spectrum) that required new methodologies that required an overthrow of classical mechanics, his postulate being that that electromagnetic energy could be emitted only in quantised form. From there, quantisation became a necessity of measurement, and with it the complications of "observables" as self-adjoint operators, rather than the 'canonical' observation of classical mechanics. The realisation, after double-slit and the rest, was that objective observation would always be limited by the fact that the process of observation would have to exist in the same quantum realm as that which is observed, and since every action has some kind of quantum effect, the conditions of that being observed and measured would always change as a consequence of measurement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14537336
>>14536628

Over the next 60 or so years after Planck, there were many theoretical physicists who then questioned the extent of this participation - Wheeler, who helped build the atom bomb, even argued for a participatory anthropic universe, i.e. a universe that we can only confirm to exist based on our conscious participation within it. Of course, again, this does not confirm subjectivity, because that's not the point. The real discovery of quantum mechanics wasn't just a mechanical model that can deal with the physical nature of reality at an atomic subatomic level wherein forces and momentum can only be understood as discrete values (quantisation), but also there are clear limits to how accurately the value of a physical quantity can be predicted prior to its measurement. A central part of that is that reality cannot be left unchanged by observation, and that, just as the observer emerges from a measurement of reality altered, that reality must be altered as well, on the quantum level. When measuring heat, a standard mercury-in-glass thermometer must absorb or release thermal energy to record a temperature, which will affect the temperature of the subject they are monitoring. It is impossible to access directly the thing-in-itself, as any activity we take to observe (as occupants of the universe) restructures the universe as we do it.

>In his 1988 University Lecture in Religion at Arizona State University, Josef van Ess argued for a widespread concept of a “compact” God in early Islam. The notion is expressed by ṣamad in Sura 112.2, an enigmatic word, which “in the first half of the second Islamic century (and probably even before) … was understood as meaning ‘massive, compact.’” There is Islamic evidence for this, van Ess argued: “The best testimony, however, comes from outside Islam: Theodore Abū Qurra, bishop of Ḥarrān in Upper Mesopotamia (ca. 750–825), translated ṣamad into Greek as sphyropēktos, a quite unusual word meaning something like ‘hammered together, closely united.’ Nicetas of Byzantium later on used holosphyros instead, ‘entirely chased in metal.’” Those familiar with the negative reception of these Byzantine translations of ṣamad by several scholars will undoubtedly be surprised by van Ess's statement, which considers the translations as trustworthy testimony. >>14541962
Not that Anon but might is whatever gives you an edge over others in a given system.
In a primitive human society, might was mostly brute force and athleticism, although even then ingenuity played a big role because you could be strategic in a fight, invent better tools etc.
This drift of human might from physical force to intellectual force only accentuated as time went by. Romans were less tall and less strong than germanics or celts but they steamrolled them thanks to better strategy and better tools.
Only when germanics were thoroughly Romanized and learned to use their tactics and equipment did they become a real threat.
So here, adaptability plays a role as another Anon said, but to me adaptability is only a function of intellect.
But there isn't a single universal context. For instance, the US is mightier than say Montenegro as a polity. But in a bar fight the montenegrin individual is mightier than the american tourist because only brute force and fighting skills matter in that context.
A human is mightier than all animals on earth thanks to his tools but a bear is mightier than a clueless ill prepared camper with no gun.
It all breaks down to the battleground, allegorical or litteral, that you chose.
China is being quite smart for instance. They know their military strength is lesser than the US one but their economu is mightier than the US one. They chose their battleground and are waging an economical war that's not intensive enough to warrant a military response. That's how they can win, by placing the confrontation in a field where they're the mightier duelist.
Does might make right? Yes, always.
Should might make right? That's a question dabbling on morality and feelings and has no universal answer as a result. It's a subject for women to discuss really.

>>14534646
I realize this doesn't have the strongest evidence behind it, which is why I'm only advancing it as a weird take, you have two censuses of the Israelite tribes in the book of Numbers; one as they're starting their wander through the desert, and another as they're almost ended, about to enter Israel.

In the first one, in Numbers 1, Simeon is a fairly large tribe, the third largest; but by the time you get to the other census, in Numbers 26, they've been brought down to almost the exact same numbers as the Levites. I tend to think all the actual numbers are made up, and that the putting Simeon's numbers on par with Levi's are an attempt to link the two tribes. Furthermore, like the Levites, they don't have a core of contiguous claimed territory within Israel (and I want to stress claim, since I think the territorial claims are about as real as the census numbers, i.e. not very). Simeon and Levi, however, have little enclaves scattered all over the place, often individual towns with little plots of land around them. The Song of Deborah doesn't mention Simeon at all, indicating they also weren't always considered a "real" tribe.

Simeon the tribe patriarch is ALWAYS linked with Levi, he never has a speaking part where he's not doing something with or to Levi. There are also a bunch of later Aggadic stories about him which usually stress his close ties with Levi, above and beyond that of the other brothers, as well as his psychopathic disposition. Some of that probably stems out of the Schechem narrative, but it paints a picture of a guy whose solution to every problem is in his scabbard.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14534190
The underpinning of slavery in Early Modern West Africa, much like Iron Age Europe, was that you had a bunch of petty kingdoms in constant conflict. These wars often consisted of brothers feuding over inheritance or disputes over tribal boundaries, so they produced a lot of what we would today call political prisoners and refugees. You'd ideally want to deport such people, and selling them into slavery in a distant land was the best way to guarantee they stayed gone.
The best treatment a foreign slave can hope for is to be treated like a retarded orphan. You're foreign, so you don't speak the language, know the culture, or have any friends here. In time you can gain all of these things, and the slave can eventually become a regular adopted member of their new community. New blood strengthens a small tribe, and letting their descendants fully integrate eliminates any of the downsides of keeping a captive population.
That said, there are plenty of examples of societies with permanent under-castes based on servile ancestry. Taking people halfway around the world to a place where their skin color will permanently mark their progeny as servants, is then especially fucked up.

>Allah is the Light of the heavens and the earth. >>14540284
>Would you consider Japonic to be Altaic?
I don't know, but it doesn't look obviously related to the core languages to the same extent that they're obviously related to each other. Maybe it branched off a long time before the others, or it was radically altered by a (Southeast Asian?) substrate, or it isn't Altaic at all.
>Why do so many linguists discard the theory?
Linguists who study Eurasian languages seem much less likely to support macrofamilies than linguists who study African languages. For example, I think the evidence for Indo-Uralic is at least as good as the evidence for Afro-Asiatic, but the former is a highly controversial theory while the latter is almost universally accepted (although the inclusion of Omotic is somewhat controversial). I don't know what causes this tendency, though.

Not really
The sun and moon deities existed and were already diferentiated from the gods relative to the sky states, you are doing a wishful thinking act
We know that the archaic Proto-Indo-European language (4500–4000) had a two-gender system which originally distinguished words between animate and inanimate, a system used to separate a common term from its deified synonym. For instance, fire as an active principle was *h1n̥gʷnis (Latin ignis; Sanskrit Agní), while the inanimate, physical entity was *péh2ur (Greek pyr; English fire)
The only way to deify the sky in a animate form is to refer to any verbalizable action it could possibly manifest, the sky shines, so the only conclussive verbalization is to refer it as shine bringer.
That said, we knoe by the existence of the very archaic and primordial sun maiden AND moon godess that the sky/celestial body on that period had a distinction.

Secular morality systems have developed throughout all history, whether it's Greek philosophers like Aristotle and Plato, or semi-religious systems like Confucianism and Buddhism. Ultimately, the society chooses what moral code they use. There is objective morality, but there are some acts that are almost universally frowned upon.

posts.com:
When we sympathize with colonized peoples we pity a weaker group being dominated by a stronger one. Conversely when we don't sympathize with a colonized people, it's because we don't see them as being weaker.
For example, you'll find very few people today who sympathize with European people colonized by the Spanish Habsburgs or Balkan people colonized by the Ottomans.
>this was a long time ago and the people have since gained their independence
these colonies existed alongside the colonization of the Americas -- peoples who today lack no sympathy despite achieving independence/decolonization concurrently with Italy and the Balkans.
Also, this was not long before colonization of Asia, who still gain anti-colonial sympathies in the West.
>people also lack sympathy when they think the colonized people deserved it.
Most Westerners would never say that Balkanites "deserved" it, the conclusion is that they do not see Balkanites as weaker than their Ottoman colonizers,
>people can also lack sympathy if they think the two groups are so similar that it isn't "one group colonizing another" but the same group
In the case of southern Italy some might argue "they're both southern european romance former romans", too similar for sympathy. This is inaccurate of course, but it's also true that almost no Westerner sees southern italians as a weaker group than spaniards.

One possible conclusion: people feel bad for colonization of non-European peoples because they believe they are weaker, not merely in the past but today, i.e. they have always been weaker. I believe this explains the instinctual pity for colonization of non-Europeans, but complete lack of pity for European colonized peoples.

All of this shows that the anti-colonialist only sympathizes with non-Europeans because he sees them as weak. His pity is based on a prejudice of non-Europeans being undeserving of colonization not because they are "the good guys", but by virtue of being weak.

>They more just lost control of the peripharies to foreign dynasties. They still controlled Egypt during the Fatimid period, pretty much all of Arabia since the founding of the Caliphate, Iraq until the Seljuks, and Hispania and North Africa until the former fell to the reconquista and the latter to colonization.

Egypt fell in the 930s to the Turkic Ikhshidid dynasty then the Arab Fatimid dynasty conquered in the late 900s. They eventually fell to the Kurdish Ayyubid dynasty in the late 1100s.

The Umayyad dynasty of Cordoba fell in 1031. There were competing Arab-led Taifas after that but most soon fell to the Amazigh Almoravid dynasty between the late 1000s and mid 1100s. Around that time came the Amazigh Almohad dynasty until the late 1200s, who were then succeeded by various Amazigh-led emirates in North Africa and the Arab-led Nasrid dynasty in Iberia.

With the exception of Iraq, the Abbassids had lost all their other territories in the late 800s. Even in Iraq, the Abbassids were puppets to the Twelver-Shia Persian Buyid dynasty since the 930s until they in turn fell to the Seljuks.

>>14540668
>All of this but also because black Americans are unironically getting bleached.
I don't think this is the case. Actually, they suffer from the negative genetic effects of outbreeding.

There are several genetic mechanisms which may cause outbreeding depression:
--Two identical alleles at the same locus can in some cases be the alternative with the highest fitness ("homozygote advantage"/"underdominance"). This is the opposite of the effect which for other loci causes inbreeding depression.
--Disruption of beneficial, synergistic interactions between loci ("coadapted gene complexes"). This is a more important cause of outbreeding depression than homozygote advantage. This effect is partly insidious since it will likely increase in strength over future generations as new genetic recombinations in each new generation break increasing numbers of such beneficial interactions.
https://archive.is/iZ5nS

Basically the more generations pass, the lower the fertility rate of the hybrid group becomes. With this basic assumption, over a long enough time, all the descendants of this kind of hybrid will disappear. This is true no matter who they choose to (attempt to) have children with.

LTA4H, or gleukotriene A4 hydrolase, is found on chromosome 17. An allele of this gene increases the risk of heart attack (the #1 cause of death in America) in Blacks by more than 250%, but only 16% in Whites. The 30% of Whites with this allele have counteracting genes, while the 6% of Black Americans who obtained it (through outbreeding) do not.
https://archive.is/RtzDl

Consistent with Haldane's rule, unmixed Blacks from Africa and White Americans do not have the same rate of birth problems that hybrid American Blacks have: "In 2005, the mortality rate for black infants was 4.4 times higher than that of white infants. African women who come to the United States and have babies experience the same low rate of infant deaths as white American mothers."
https://archive.is/oYZm9

Newton saw God as the masterful creator whose existence could not be denied in the face of the grandeur of all creation.[19] Nevertheless, he rejected Leibniz's thesis that God would necessarily make a perfect world which requires no intervention from the creator. For while comets move in very eccentric orbs in all manner of positions, blind fate could never make all the planets move one and the same way in orbs concentric, some inconsiderable irregularities excepted which may have arisen from the mutual actions of comets and planets on one another, and which will be apt to increase, till this system wants a reformation.[20]

Has been tried before, it's a failure.
The flaws with Socialism and planned economies are well known and unavoidable. You will never escape the economic calculation problem. The more you distort the economy the less you can read it and accurately decide how to allocate resources in the most efficient manner. Government intervention in the economy will always be worse than a market economy in the long run.
The actual answer is that the government should leave the economy entirely to the market, levy taxes on income and profits, and then redistribute that money among the poorest sector of society. Ideally this would take the form of direct payments to be used by the beneficiaries at their discretion. Government run welfare institutions tend to be either absolute garbage or resource sink holes which demand an ever increasing budget to fund an ever enlarging bureaucracy (look at the NHS).

>>14538729
The Soviet Union tried to control the uncontrolable industries too. They tried to control their entire nation's manufacturing sector. I am not suggesting this.

One of the cheapest places in the world to buy gasoline at the pump is, unsurprisingly, Saudi Arabia. They have been, and still are, the top oil exporter for deccades. All of that oil flows out of the country except for a small percentage earmarked for domestic use. The internal market for that fuel is small and easily predictable; the supply is so large and the margins so small that the sales will always grow to meet demand. It is an incredibly uncompetitive market.
Of course, the export of oil is the single most important part of Saudi Arabia's economy and provides the vast majority of the economy's raw wealth. But as an internal product sold within the nation's internal economy, petroleum producs are a very minor part of Saudi Arabia's economy.
When the chief export of the country is nationalized, the vast majority of its sales remain under market regulation; the regulation of the internation market, which the nation cannot control. It is only the very minor internal sales that become planned when the chief export is nationalized, and so it avoids the brunt of the economic calculation problem

Anyway, cool graph. If you compare it to Britain's population growth over the past 15 years, you'll see that the NHS is consistently getting less funding than it needs compared to the number of patients it needs to serve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14536082
Now, your polemic comes from the assumption that all Christian theories of atonement are vicarious in nature, which is simply not true. The New Testament never lays out any concrete doctrine on how Jesus's death or blood actually makes atonement for us, the closest thing you're going to find in it is the Ransom Theory but there is nothing explicit about that. Everyone in the ancient world understood sacrifice as like divine currency. The importance of blood in atonement is certainly present in Judaism and the Tanakh, specifically in the priestly source: Leviticus 4:35 and 5:9 specifically connect it with forgiveness and expiation. More importantly though, it was used in establishing a covenant as in the case of Noah, Abraham, and Moses. Was blood always necessary for atonement? Not always, prayer and repentance played a role too and Leviticus 5:11 has grain offerings in place of sin offerings for atonement. But the importance of prayer and repentance are important for forgivness in the New Testament too: Acts 2:28, Luke 24:47, 1 John 1:7-9, the list goes on. The New Testament instead understands Jesus's sacrifice as a kind of chatat for all believers, past, present, and future, and like Judaism of the post Temple period, puts a heavy emphasis on repentance and faithfulness as necessary for forgiveness as well.

Finally, the Judaism of Jesus's time most certainly had a precursor concept of a righteous man and his blood being able to make atonement for sins. 4 Maccabees 6:28-29 reads: "Be merciful to your people, and let our punishment suffice for them. Make my blood their purification, and take my life in exchange for theirs”. The idea of righteous martyrs standing in place, doing a kind of "penance" on behalf of Israel's sins, did exist at this time and mostly arose out the context of the Maccabean revolt (as did the Jewish idea about a future resurrection of the righteous). The motif of the righteous martyr further appears in Wisdom 2-5.

posts.com:
1))) Leaving home

Jesus "leaves" the "maternal womb", the home, to fulfill its obligations with the mankind on two occasions: the first when he incarnates as a human, and the second one, when he begins his ministry at the age of 33. Similar to Odysseus reluctantly leaving Ithaca, both have great destinies from Providence to fullfill.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14540979
2))) The companions of the initial journey, the inititation and the first test

Once his journey has begun, he meets those who will be his traveling companions, men of various origins, who will accompany him throughout his journey, and who will have their own journeys and tragedies, like heroes, when Jesus returns to his home, in Heaven, at the right hand of the Father. The 12 apostles, who would become what Enkidu is to Gilgamesh, or the Olympians accompanying Zeus in the Titanomachy.

Jesus receives his initiation from his cousin John the Baptist, being baptized in the Jordan River, to enter the Judean desert, where fasting for 40 days and nights, he is tempted by the Devil, thus confirming his initiation, similar to what we are told in 300 (the film) about the confirmation of Leonidas by defeating the Wolf when he is abandoned in the forest or Buddha, who was also tempted, or, like Frodo's Journey to Rivendell, which confirms Frodo's willpower before the assembly/church/lodge, which precedes the Journey to Mordor. If we compare it with Odysseus, this moment would be the Trojan War, which precedes the Journey to Ithaca.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14540987
3))) The enemies on the way

Once this first stage of the journey is over, Jesus begins to face all sorts of adversaries on the way and makes miracles to help people, healing the sick, raising the dead and feeding the masses. The attacks of the Pharisees and Sadducees who question his authority, the demons who have possessed by various unfortunates that Jesus meets on his pilgrimage through Judea, the Wind that tries to bring down the ship of the apostles and Satan, who continues to tempt him so that he turns away from his final task, the salvation of the human race in an expiatory sacrifice. This would be similar to Gilgamesh's Journey to the East after the death of Enkidu, where he faces various adversaries, or the 12 labors of Hercules to atone for his sins against his family.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14541000
4))) The betrayal and apparent death of the hero

Jesus is finally betrayed by Judas Iscariot, who, possessed by Satan, delivers Jesus to the Romans and the Pharisees, who deliver him to his greatest enemy, death, Jesus as God constantly links himself to life, the inmortality...

>14 But whosoever drinketh of the water that I shall give him shall never thirst; but the water that I shall give him shall be in him a well of water springing up into everlasting life.

This reminds us of the betrayal of Gollum, the betrayal of Brutus to Caesar and the betrayal of Ephialtes to Leonidas, Jesus has to climb Mount Golgota just like Frodo the Mount of destiny and Leonidas & his men have to face death, or absolute surrender. But the hero never gives up and continues the battle to the end dying tragically before their enemies, how joyful they believe they have obtained the victory.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14541008
5))) The resurrection and victory

Jesus finally defeats Death and Satan, triumphing on the third day, has spiritually won the victory over Satan, so that those who believe in him have eternal life even if their bodies are destroyed. Jesus and his transit through hell/underworld is similar to Gilgamesh's transit through hell, before reaching Noah, or that of Odysseus after surpassing Circe. But unlike Gilgamesh, Jesus achieves victory over Death and the Serpent. After his resurrection, Jesus tries to comfort his mortal friends, who have not yet been enlightened by the Holy Spirit, educates and instructs them, and finally ascends on a cloud to Heaven to return to God, the Father. Similar to Caesar's ascension into heaven as a victorious God in the form of Halley's Comet, as his son Augustus exclaimed, Caesar has conquered death to be a God, we see the same in Frodo on his journey to Arda. The hero cannot return home, he must ascend (Jesus, Buddha, Caesar, Leonidas) or fail (Hercules, Gilgamesh).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14541012
6))) Pentecost and the preaching of the Gospel

Those close to the hero fall before the death of his friend, in doubt and despair, Jesus is buried with honors, and the apostles hide from the persecution of the Pharisees and Romans. Peter himself came to deny Jesus 3 times, and all remained hidden even after the resurrection until the day of Pentecost, when the Holy Spirit is poured out on them, the possession by the Heroic spirit as Jesus during their baptism, now the court of followers of Jesus, they are confirmed (they were initiated by performing the first Eucharist at The last supper) and will undertake their own journeys around the world, founding churches, expelling demons, fighting fake prophets, facing persecution and following the example of their friend and leader, Jesus. Likewise, the Spartans found themselves heartbroken by the death of their king, and those close to Caesar after the betrayal of the Senate, but all of them inspired by the fallen-resurrected hero, undertake their own war against their enemies.
